page.title: 10Tubney
page.content: The Tubney Tree,a large dead elm,marks the boundary of Fyfield and Tubney.It is not known locally as the Fyfield Elm which is how Mathew Arnold immortalized it in his poetry. Opposite are cottages on either side of the road, a few sadly have modern extensions. Half way along the road is a an old V.R. post box still in use, actually set into its sidewall, Well cottage, the telephone box and notice board proclaiming a Mondays only bus service.Large houses hiding in secluded gardens form the southern end of the village, bordered by Frilford Heath Golf Club.Opposite the notice board is a lodge by the gated front drive,lined with beautiful old trees leading to Tubney House,nicknamed Parsons Castle because the banker of that name built the balustrades.The back drive leads to St.Lawrence Church(Welby Pugin l847)
